THE FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
In the past 5 years, there have been no accidental releases from covered processes with regulated substances held above threshold quantities that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage that may have resulted from any activities or incidents at the Carter Creek Gas Plant.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Carter Creek Gas Plant maintains a written Emergency Response Plan, which is in place to protect public safety and worker safety (both employees and contractors), as well as the environment, and to minimize effects in the unlikely event of an emergency. The plan consists of detailed procedures for responding to accidental releases of toxic and flammable substances.  
These response procedures address the following aspects of emergency response, and more: 
* First aid;
* Evacuation plans which include provisions for accounting for all personnel (employees, contractors, and visitors) after an evacuation.
* Notification to appropriate emergency response agencies; and
* Post-incident cleanup and decontamination.

Facility personnel actively coordinate with local emergency responders and participate on the Uinta County LEPC to plan and practice for emergency response issues in the area. 

The CCGP Emergency Response Organization consists of approximately 5-10 trained individuals. These individuals are trained to respond to emergencies at the facility.

The training these individuals receive is in Incident Command, Emergency Response, Confined Space Response, Basic Emergency Care, P.P.E., and basic Rescue Techniques. They have training that ensures they know how to respond to areas and processes of the facility and know how to deal with the hazards associated with those areas and processes.

The calculated maximum distance to the toxic endpoint (0.042 mg/L or 30ppm; Basis ERPG-2) for the WCS of Process 3 is beyond the facility boundary, but there are no public receptors within that calculated radius due to the remote location of the facility.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
Hilcorp encourages employees to participate in all aspects of Process Safety Management and accident prevention.  As such, facility employees have access to the information created as part of the facility Process Safety Management and accident prevention programs. 

The processes are controlled and monitored using instruments trained personnel and protective systems (e.g. distributive control systems, automated detection, emergency shutdown systems, closed blowdown systems, pressure relief valves, pressure control valves, remotely located flare systems, etc.).

CCGP has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

CCGP maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, and (5) normal shutdown. 

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Hilcorp has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating CCGP

CCGP uses Management of change processes to control and track Facility changes 

Mechanical Integrity programs including on-line equipment testing (e.g. ultrasonic thickness testing, radiographic inspection, corrosion coupons, etc.), chemical inhibition to control corrosion, equipment preventative maint

ned processes with threshold quantities of regulated substances at CCGP including:

Process 1:

Inlet flows and quantities of flammable, naturally occurring hydrocarbon mixtures of methane, ethane, propane, butane and pentane. 

Process 2:

Flammable hydrocarbon mixtures of methane, ethane, propane, butane, pentane associated with NGL removal from the sales gas stream and propane refrigeration systems. 

Process 3:

Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) associated with the naturally occurring hydrocarbon mixture of natural gas entering the Gas Plant and the associated Sulfur Recovery Unit used to remove the H2S from the gas and convert the H2S to elemental Sulfur. 


WORST CASE SENARIOS

Process 1: 
Worst-case scenario (WCS) for Process 1 is a loss of containment of the V-1101 (Slug Catcher) vessel contents, releasing the entire vessel volume (284,000 lbs.), resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The facility has numerous controls in place to prevent such releases and to manage the consequences.  The calculated maximum distance to endpoint (1 psi overpressure) for the WCS of Process 1 is beyond the facility boundary, but there are no public receptors within that calculated radius due to the remote location of the facility.

Process 2:
Worst-case scenario (WCS) for Process 2 is a loss of containment of the V-1301 (Glycol Separator) vessel contents releasing the entire vessel volume of 30,500lb including gas and NGLs resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The facility has numerous controls in place to prevent such releases and to manage their consequences.  The calculated maximum distance to endpoint (1 psi overpressure) for the WCS of Process 2 is beyond the facility boundary, but there are no public receptors within that calculated radius due to the remote location of the facility.

Worst-case scenario (WCS) for Process 3 is the loss of containment of the V-1101 (Slug Catcher) vessel contents to the atmosphere resulting in the entire volume of H2S (7,500 lbs) being relea

d to strip the H2S and CO2 from the gas stream. 

Process 2 Dehydration and NGL Extraction

The treated, high-pressure gas from the Diethanolamine unit (meeting pipeline specification) is sent to Process 2 for dehydration and natural gas liquid (NGL) extraction.  Dehydration is accomplished through injection of Ethylene Glycol into the gas stream upstream of the gas chiller.  

Treated, high-pressure gas is chilled to -20 deg. F in the High-Pressure Sweet Gas Chiller (V-1302) to achieve a required sales gas hydrocarbon dew point requirement of 15deg. F and a gas water content of 7 lb/MMSCF.  Extracted natural gas liquids  are then sold as stabilized NGL product via a NGL Pipeline. Chilling is accomplished through propane refrigeration.  

The full stream is then sent to V-1301 (Glycol Separator) where the natural gas, ethylene glycol, and NGLs are separated.  The NGLs are stabilized (de-methanized) and then shipped to the NGL sales pipeline.  (Enterprise Products)


Process 3- H2S removal and Sulfur recovery

The sour natural gas from Process 1 is sent to an amine treating unit where diethanolamine (DEA) is used to strip H2S and CO2 from the gas stream.  

The DEA is regenerated to produce a gas stream containing H2S, CO2, and water vapor (Acid Gas) which is further processed for conversion to elemental sulfur in a 3-Stage Claus unit. The regenerated DEA is recirculated back to the H2S Absorbers.

The H2S liberated from the DEA is reacted and converted to elemental sulfur utilizing a Claus Sulfur Recovery process (SRU).  The residual gas stream after the Claus unit is treated in the Tail Gas Unit which includes reactors to convert sulfur species back the H2S and a Flexsorb unit to selectively remove residual H2S from the Tail Gas Stream.  

The tail gas from the Plant is then heated and lofted to the atmosphere at or below Wyoming State DEQ permitted levels for emission components.

REGULATED SUBSTANCES ABOVE THRESHOLD QUANTITIES AT CCGP

FACILITY DESCRIPTION

	The Carter Creek Gas Plant (CCGP) is owned and operated by Hilcorp Energy Company. The gas plant, located in the Whitney Canyon / Carter Creek gas field (approx. 21 miles North and East of Evanston, Wyoming), was originally designed to process approximately 150 MMscfd of natural occurring natural gas.
	
	Hilcorp employs approximately 28 full time employees and contractors at the facility.   

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

It is the policy of Hilcorp Energy Company to conduct business in a responsible and ethical manner that protects the safety and health of employees and the public as well as protecting the environment. The CCGP Emergency Action Plan covers procedures for reporting fires or other emergencies, emergency evacuation and exit routes, procedures for employees who remain to operate critical plant operations prior to evacuation, accounting for personnel, rescue and medical duties, and contact information for employees responsible for plan implementation and who can provide more information to other employees about the plan.  The Emergency Action Plan also involves coordination with local emergency response personnel and routine drills and table top exercises.   


PRIMARY ACTIVITIES

Process 1- Well Stream separation, stabilization, and 

The well stream separation area at the plant inlet takes in the natural gas from the field and provides gas/liquid separation and stabilization.  It is designed to handle about 150 MMscfd of natural gas per day. 

The well stream enters the plant as a three-phase stream: gas, hydrocarbon condensate, and free water. The gas and liquid are separated in V-1101 (Slug Catcher). The gas is then filtered and treated. The hydrocarbon condensate is de-pressured, stripped of H2S, and stabilized. The free water is degassed of H2S and sent to a sour liquids blowdown system.
